Summary I am currently a PhD candidate at the University of Georgia. My focus is computer vision with a PhD minor in artificial intelligence. My research is on modeling human visual attention using deep learning. I have accepted a software development position at Google (in Mountain View, CA) to begin once I graduate. 
 
My most recent work experience was as a PhD Software Engineering Intern at Google in Mountain View, CA. I worked on Street View and had an amazing time. I felt well-prepared for the position having interned as a developer at Lithium Technologies the previous summer and from teaching multiple programming courses at UGA. I left the internship a more confident developer with a better perspective of how my work can effect change in the world.

Experience Software Engineering Intern, PhD Google May 2014  –  August 2014  (4 months) Mountain View, CA I worked on Street View for my summer internship at Google. My project involved predicting the best place to look in panoramas. I used computer vision and machine learning techniques to build a set of classes to solve the problem. The project was really perfect for me, since I love computer vision, machine learning, maps, and photography. It also fit very well with my doctoral research which involves predicting where people look in images. 
 
Most of my work was done in C++ and I made use of many internal Google technologies. For example, I used MapReduce to distribute work on large datasets and Bigtable to cache results. I also used JavaScript to build an interactive demo of my product. In the end, I had a multithreaded production-ready product. 
 
There were plenty of other opportunities I was able to take advantage of at Google. I filed a patent, found and fixed bugs in other products, and provided feedback on unreleased products. I also met many people that inspired and encouraged me. I definitely learned a lot about writing high-quality tested code to work at scale. Software Development Intern Lithium Technologies June 2013  –  August 2013  (3 months) San Francisco, CA My primary responsibility over the summer was to refactor a customer-facing feature to fix bugs, improve security, and better organize the code. I had to go down many paths before finally finding the best solution, but in the end, I was proud of the work that went in the release. Along the way, I learned a lot about agile development, testing, and the varied responsibilities of a software developer. 
 
Thanks to the well-designed intern program at Lithium, I also discovered other roles in the company. I had the opportunity to mock up some UX designs for a scalable multi-phase web staging back end, then present iterations to the UX team for feedback. I regularly interacted with different team members to get their perspective, and I met executives from Engineering, Human Resources, and Marketing. I even made a sales pitch video that was shown in front of the entire international sales staff! 
 
Furthermore, getting to live in San Francisco was an eye opening experience. I gained new perspectives by attending talks, meetups, and by visiting colleagues at other companies. The coffee wasn't half bad, either! It's hard to believe how much I learned in just under two months. Technical Consultant NRG Ceramics June 2011  –  September 2012  (1 year 4 months) Doraville, GA Focused on using software to improve efficiency. Utilized QuickBooks for Mac and NRGship UPS shipping software for Mac. Filmed, edited, and produced a DVD of the manufacturing process. Designed software to better communicate priorities to the manufacturers. Network Engineer Intern BlueWave Computing May 2009  –  December 2010  (1 year 8 months) Monitor server alerts, solve problems remotely, website maintenance. Worked with Microsoft Exchange, Symantec Backup Exec, Symantec Endpoint Security, Ipswitch WhatsUp, and other common server-side applications. Summer IT Intern Moore Ingram Johnson & Steele May 2007  –  August 2008  (1 year 4 months) Over the summers of 2007 and 2008, I supported over 100 computers running Microsoft software, assisted with various technical tasks, and improved workflow by automating common tasks. Specifics include: 
 
- Assisted in managing Citrix, Microsoft Exchange, and file servers running Microsoft Windows Server 
- Created a digital dictation system, modernizing the old method of using tapes, by which attorneys may dictate from anywhere, then send it back to the office to be transcribed 
- Programmed batch files to improve setup of new computers 
- Oversaw tape backups IT Support Dr. Baker Management Center May 2001  –  August 2006  (5 years 4 months) Over a number of years, I worked directly with Dr. Larry Baker on a variety of tasks, including: 
 
- Set up a KickStartCart.com shopping cart with products, autoresponders, and an Authorize.Net payment gateway. 
- Worked with a web developer on search engine optimization 
- Helped with web site maintenance in Microsoft FrontPage and later, Dreamweaver

Summary Hello, my name is Scott Ruoti. I am currently a PhD candidate in Computer Science at Brigham Young University. I conduct interest in the area of usability security. My research projects fall under the categories of improving password-based authentication and providing simple-to-use secure online communications. I am especially interested in research that address the concerns of not only security experts, but also businesses and users, as I feel this is necessary for any research to reach widespread deployment. 
 
I have previously worked at a start-up (Computer Lab Solutions) and Brigham Young University developing lab management technologies deployed to hundreds of universities. Additionally, I have successfully completed internships with Microsoft, Microsoft Research, Google, and Blue Coat Systems.

Summary Mission-oriented software engineering at Palantir Technologies. Solving some of the world's hardest problems for some of the world's most important organizations. I strongly believe that mission and impact are what really matter. 
 
Currently working in government-based projects at Palantir. As a Forward Deployed Engineer, I work on end-to-end solutions with some of our clients: from finding the organization hardest unsolved problems, to building a product vision on how to achieve success, to executing on that vision - data integration, extensions do Palantir technology, building new, customized, customer-specific tech. 
 
Previously done software engineering and Computer Security research, with a background in Computer Science, specifically computer networks and mobile computing. Recently worked on the Chrome OS Security team at Google. Research experience include: software security analysis, mobile security middleware, mobile networks, intrusion detection, social networks (crawling and analysis) and wireless sensor networks. Experience on industry as software/web application developer. Years as a developer in most active technologies (C, C++, Java (incl. J2EE, JSP, ...), CoffeeScript, PHP, ASP, Perl, etc.). Recently worked on the Chrome OS Security team at Google. Research experience include: software security analysis, mobile security middleware, mobile networks, intrusion detection, social networks (crawling and analysis) and wireless sensor networks. Experience on industry as software/web application developer. Years as a developer in most active technologies (C, C++, Java (incl. J2EE, JSP, ...), CoffeeScript, PHP, ASP, Perl, etc.). Mission-oriented software engineering at Palantir Technologies. Solving some of the world's hardest problems for some of the world's most important organizations. I strongly believe that mission and impact are what really matter.

Summary I am currently a PhD Candidate at Columbia University in Electrical Engineering (EE), 2012-2015 National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate (NDSEG) Fellow. I received my B.S. Summa Cum Laude in EE in 2008 from New York University, Brooklyn, NY and my M.S. in ECE at Carnegie Mellon University (CMU), Pittsburgh, PA in 2011. In 2012, I was a Brown Institute of Media Innovation Magic Grant recipient. 
 
My most recent three positions can be summarized roughly in A+B relations: 
* deep learning + video processing @ Google 
* multimedia + computer vision @ Columbia 
* machine learning + wearables @ Technicolor 
 
My expertise and research lies at the union of computer vision and multimedia, intersecting machine learning. I've worked in some span of this technology space for the better part of the past decade, and my work has won awards/honors at academic conferences as well as been featured on national/local television. 
 
Prior to my PhD, I was the Technical Project Manager at the CMU CyLab Biometrics Center where I oversaw facial and iris recognition projects. Previously, I also worked at Consolidated Edison on the Growth Opportunities for Leadership Development (GOLD) Program as a Management Associate, where I filled both engineering and supervisory roles. 
 
Specialties: Management (Engineering / Technical Projects & Products / Software), Electrical Engineering & Computer Science (Computer Vision / Multimedia / Image&Video Processing / Affective Computing / Signal Processing), Machine Learning & Pattern Recognition (Data Science / Optimization / Statistical Modeling / Multimodal Computing / Information Retrieval), Programming (Python / C++ / MATLAB / Shell / HTML/CSS) Summary I am currently a PhD Candidate at Columbia University in Electrical Engineering (EE), 2012-2015 National Defense Science and Engineering Graduate (NDSEG) Fellow. Summary My name is Joseph Ellis, and I am currently an Electrical Engineering PhD candidate at Columbia University, under the supervision of Professor Shih-Fu Chang. My graduate research has been funded by the NSF IGERT: From Data to Solutions program, and I am currently an NSF Graduate Research Fellow. I have worked at Qualcomm and The Mitre Corporation both located in San Diego, California. My research interests lie in the intersection of Multimedia, Machine Learning, and Computer Vision. I developed the award-winning NewsRover system at Columbia University, and have also conducted research in the field of image tracking. Please see my Google Scholar Page for more details. I currently hold a U.S. Government Top Secret Security Clearance. 
 
I am an currently an intern with the Relatedness Matrix team in the Google Search department. I work on machine learning algorithms for ranking and clustering structured entities across Google products. NSF GFRP Fellow Columbia University in the City of New York September 2014  – Present (1 year) Research Staff Intern IBM June 2014  – Present (1 year 3 months) yorktown heights, new york At IBM Research I worked on novel algorithms and mathematical formulations for emotion analysis of movie clips. NSF IGERT Trainee (PhD) Columbia University September 2012  –  June 2014  (1 year 10 months) greater new york city area As an IGERT Trainee/PhD Candidate at Columbia University I performed research in Machine Learning and Multimedia Engineering under the supervision of Senior Vice Dean Shih-Fu Chang. I developed the award winning NewsRover system. NewsRover is a novel system for aggregating, analyzing, and presenting heterogeneous news content. NewsRover uses novel algorithms and technologies for person identification, text-video matching, and news-event clustering. Electrical Engineer (Communications) MITRE February 2012  –  July 2012  (6 months) greater san diego area I worked on a variety of projects concerned with navigation and tracking algorithims. I created a Matlab model of an Inertial Navigation System that evaluated the errors that would propogate throughout the INS given gyroscope and accelerometer biases and initial alignment errors. The model propogated the errors based on a flight path and aircraft acceleration as inputs. 
 
I performed a study on the current capabilites and limitations of military software defined radios, and specifically the HMS Rifleman Radio. The study was presented to seven different government entities such as DARPA, and the JTRS office. 
 
I aided government officials in the operation and execution of the multiple Government Developmental Tests and Mission Operational Test and Evaluations for the HMS program. I also created reports and presentations analyzing the data from these tests that were presented to the Army Chief Acquisition Officer. Technical Intern MITRE June 2011  –  January 2012  (8 months) Greater San Diego Area I created a mathematical model to analyze the capabilities of current tactical communication networks. Worked on a three-person team to create new enhancements for tactical communication networks, and I also helped to coordinate two weeks of Army test exercises at White Sands Missile Range, New Mexico Undergraduate Student Researcher University of San Diego June 2010  –  June 2011  (1 year 1 month) Greater San Diego Area I recieved a research grant and then conducted paid research in Image Tracking. I was published in the proceedings the 5th Annual National Security Innovation Competition and ICSEng 2011. I also presented my work at these two conferences in Colorado Springs, Colorado and Las Vegas, Nevada.  Graduate Research Assistant @Physics UC Berkeley January 2011  – Present (4 years 8 months) Berkeley, California AFM Near Field Detection (2014):  
-Set up an AFM system with FIR (~10um) CO2 laser coupled to measure the locally enhanced near field signal on sample. Detection is done using LN2-cooled HgCdTe (MCT). Signal is measured with a lock-in amplifier to demodulate higher order harmonics.  
-Developed method to use spin-coated thermal-sensitive ink for accurate focusing.  
-Developed method to use a heat-sensitive modulation signal for rough laser-AFM tip alignment.  
 
Nanotube Imaging and Absorption Spectrum (2014):  
-Set up together with group members a polarization-enhanced imaging system that allows clear imaging of highly anisotropic nano-particles: the carbon nanotube.  
-Developed a method to use lock-in amplifier and modulated scanning to even increase the detection sensitivity.  
-Developed Labview automation code for data acquisition and experiment control. 
 
Graphene-Metamaterial (2013):  
-Numerical simulation and analytical modeling of a hybrid graphene-metamaterial device that enhances IR-RF transmission modulation ~10x .  
-Performed experiment with others using a THz wave setup.  
-Measurement is performed using THz time domain spectroscopy that involves electrical-optical sampling, lock-in amplifier and labview coding. 
 
Grating Design and Modeling (2013):  
-Conducted numerical simulation and analytical modeling of a new type of grating called “diatomic” dielectric gratings.  
-Modeling is performed using Mathematica and is then validated by FDTD and RCWA simulation. This type of dielectric grating achieves tunable high Q resonances better than the High Contrast Grating. 
 
Higher Harmonic Generation in optical antenna (2012).  
-Designed and conducted experiment to detect higher harmonic generation from fabricated optical antenna. Light source is OPO tunable infrared light and focused using a reflective lens.  
-Built a high sensitive spectrometer using a photo multiplier tube (PMT) coupled with third party gratings for 2 and 3rd order harmonic detection. Graduate Research Intern Google March 2014  –  June 2014  (4 months) Mountain View, California Google[x] Lab

Grating Design and Modeling (2013):  
-Conducted numerical simulation and analytical modeling of a new type of grating called “diatomic” dielectric gratings.  
-Modeling is performed using Mathematica and is then validated by FDTD and RCWA simulation. This type of dielectric grating achieves tunable high Q resonances better than the High Contrast Grating.
